physicalContactObject: black Tesla-branded insulated water bottle with silver lid
physicalSubstrateObject: yellow UHU adhesive glue tube
contactUtilizationMethod: Grasp the bottle 2–3 cm above its base so that most of the mass (filled liquid + metal cap) sits forward of the hand. This creates a mild head-heavy feel and the cylindrical body gives the fingers a firm, full power-grip similar to a hammer handle. Swing the wrist in short arcs; the inertia of the bottle reproduces the weighted head sensation.
substrateUtilizationMethod: Place the closed glue tube horizontally on the tabletop so it cannot roll. With the bottle gripped like a hammer, strike the mid-section of the tube using the base edge of the bottle. The thin, laminated foil skin momentarily resists and then dents, allowing the soft viscous glue inside to redistribute. This instant drop in resistance after the initial firm contact produces a clear "pop-through" feeling that mimics the watermelon rind giving way.
expectedHapticFeedback: The user should then experience a distinct "breakthrough" moment as the hammer penetrates the rind - a sudden release of resistance like breaking through a moderately tough shell
harmony_explanation: The foil tube gives a brief shell-like resistance then a sudden yield, producing a pop-through sensation similar to cracking a rind, but the small scale and low force magnitude reduce the perceived weight and impact timing slightly.
expressivity_explanation: The thin foil surface provides a distinct initial resistance followed by a sudden give as the glue redistributes, creating a convincing two-phase breakthrough sensation.
realism_explanation: The initial foil resistance and sudden dent give a convincing pop-through moment, but the scale and softness of the tube underplay the firmness of a real watermelon rind.
